- 2 -
that mountainless end of the island and on to Hongkong where we landed early
in the afternoon.
We were met by E. M.
Allison,
Ki
Chun and Colonel C. Y.
Liu and Jerry 0'Donnell,
PAA #1.
The latter had secured a double room for
us in
the Gloucester
Hotel - one room being equipped with an air-conditioning
machine - very
humidity.
welcome 'cause Hongkong is about 90 in both temperature and
That night we had Chinese
chow - Szechuan style - with Max Polin.
I had forgot just how
good it was !
The next day - Tuesday May 31 - we flew over to Canton with Colonel
Liu, M.D.
of CNAC,
to pay our respects on the Minister of Communications.
It
was a perfectly useless trip because he is of no importance and doesn't know
anything about flying in general or CNAC in particular but the trip was
required by
protocol.
Arriving early at the airport we learned that the night
before the whole cabinet of Ho Ying-Chin had resigned - so our visit was
even less important.
However, we went through with it and were rewarded by
a nice luncheon party in a bamboo grove on the outskirts of Canton not far
from the large rambling old residence which serves as
the temporary head-
quarters for the Ministry.
They are getting ready to move all the smsll-fry
clerks to Chungking while the big shots will
go to Formosa.
By a coincidence
only, of course,
al1
the monetary funds - some 250 million US dollars -
are
on Formosa !
The new premier - old General Yen Shi-shan - is still forming
his cabinet and may or may not reappoint our
present Minister of Communications.
The latter
like all
other Chinese officials - would rather not serve.
They'd
all rather be free to make deals with the "Liberation" authorities.
Old Gen-
eral Yen is
the same
war lord who ran Shensi Province from 1911 until the Con-
munists captured his
capital of Tai Yuan-fu some months ago.
When the Japs
threatened Tai Yuan-fu he drove all around the elty with a big sign which
announced thet he would be "s stinking furtle" - about as complimentary as
calling a Frenchman a pig - if he surrendered to the Japanese.
The next day
he left
with 20
truckloads of personal effects.
He did put up & great battle
against the Communists and announced that he would die with his troops - but
he. didn't.
After lunch we drove into Shameen to see Lewis Clark, American
Minister.
Did some shopping but found nothing.
Canton is just
the same ex-
cept that most of the rickshas are "bike"
powered - which makes the traffic
worse.
Returning to Hongkong.
It also re ains about the same -
outwardly.
However, all is changed.
over.
The old taipans are gone.
Chinese have taken
They have invaded the Peak where formerly none but the first families
of British were permitted to live.
They have taken over the best hotels.
The Hongkong Hotel at "elevens" is 90% Chiness.
Stayed in Hongkong until Thursday then flew over to Manila to see
the new Anerican Ambassador Mr. Marvin Cowan, nee Cohen.
Spent Fridey in
Manile.
Lou would never recognize the place.
Both wings of the magnificent
Government building - where the legislature sat - were shot to pieces and
have been torn down.
The old intramures is a mass of ruins with only an arch
or two remaining of
the magnificent old churches.
MacArthur Is old headquarters
in the corner of the wall are not only gone but the wall too is no more.
I
stayed at the Manila Hotel which has been largely restored except that the fur-
niture is "ratty" and the whole place has a "down-at-the-heels"
Friday night I went out on to
atmosphere.
the dance floor about 11:30 to find
American (in shirt
only one
sleeves) and perhaps 100 Filipinos.
